'Honor those detainers, and then we won't have to flood the zone with our ICE law enforcement.'

"We're seeing that these criminal illegal aliens are exiting the jails and going back on to New York, or Chicago, or these other sanctuary streets to re-perpetuate their crimes," DHS Assistant Secretary Tricia McLaughlin told Fox News.

"Today, in New York City's jails are 7,169 criminal illegal aliens," McLaughlin continued. "We're talking about hundreds of murderers, hundreds of sexual predators, drug traffickers, the worst of the worst."

McLaughlin encouraged sanctuary city politicians to cooperate with immigration officials to remove these known threats from the country.

"Honor those detainers, and then we won't have to flood the zone with our ICE law enforcement. We won't have to put those men and women on the ground because we will get these vicious criminals out of New York City's jails," McLaughlin added.

"What New Yorkers are looking for is an era of consistency. An era of clarity and an era of conviction. And that's what we will deliver to them."

title: Conservative winces as he's forced to admit Dems 'on a roll' — and GOP a 'rudderless ship'
text:
Democratic National Committee Chair Ken Martin boasted last week that the “Democratic Party is back” following the party’s sweeping victories in last month’s elections, and conservative commentator Joe Concha, when pressed Monday on Fox Business to respond, winced before conceding to the claim.

Democrats had a strong showing last month after winning two contested gubernatorial races in Virginia and New Jersey, expanding their House majority in the Virginia legislature, winning races in Virginia for lieutenant governor and attorney general, and fending off independent mayoral candidate Andrew Cuomo with Zohran Mamdani's victory in New York City.

Appearing with Fox Business’ Stuart Varney Monday, Concha was asked to respond to Martin’s comments, to which Concha’s immediate reaction was to disparage the head of the DNC.

“Martin is the same guy who hired that human broomstick David Hogg to be his number two with the DNC,” Concha said, while calling the Democratic Party a “party that lacks testosterone.”

Addressing Martin’s claims directly, however, Concha was forced to admit that the DNC head had a point.

“But then again, Democrats are on a roll lately winning in New Jersey, Virginia and New York City,” Concha admitted. 

“I get those are blue areas, but at the same time, it appears that – at least the way things are going right now – that this is the party that has momentum, and Republicans seem to be a rudderless ship at this point.”

Martin’s comments were made to Politico last Thursday, where he strongly suggested that Democrats would cruise to victory in the impending midterm elections that, as of December, are less than a year out.

“We won across the board with every major constituency that left our party last year, and that should tell you something again,” Martin told Politico, “that the Democratic Party is back.”

summary: Misused pandemic funds, luxury travel, and declining achievement reveal a crisis of priorities—one only school choice can fix.
title: Chicago Is the Latest Example of How Public School Spending Doesn't Prioritize Students
text:
Public school districts have a responsibility to educate students, safeguard taxpayer money, and provide families with opportunities for success. However, Chicago Public Schools (CPS) has become a national example of how a school system collapses under mismanagement, political patronage, and an absence of accountability.

A report from the Chicago Board of Education's Office of Inspector General uncovered $23.6 million in misused spending—specifically, spending on lavish and often unapproved travel: $1,000-a-night hotel rooms, airport limos, luxury suites, and "professional development" trips that doubled as vacations. One teacher stretched a four-day seminar into a weeklong Hawaiian resort stay costing $4,700.

A principal booked a Las Vegas Strip suite for an anniversary celebration and extended the trip without authorization. In another incident, 24 employees from one school spent $50,000 to attend a Las Vegas conference. More than $142,000 was spent on overseas trips to South Africa, Finland, Estonia, and Egypt—complete with hot-air balloon rides and game-park safaris.

The abuses skyrocketed further when federal pandemic funds loosened district budgets. Of the $23.6 million, $14.5 million was spent in 2023 and 2024 alone. These dollars were intended to address severe learning loss after the Chicago Teachers Union forced schools to remain closed for 78 weeks during the pandemic. Instead of supporting students' academic recovery, millions became a travel fund.

That level of waste is why students like me need school choice. When a district spends public money this irresponsibly while failing to educate its students, families deserve the freedom to go elsewhere.

Meanwhile, only two in five CPS students read at grade level, and barely one in four meets math expectations. In some neighborhoods, proficiency falls into the single digits. Nearly 45 percent of students—and more than half of high schoolers—are chronically absent. These figures reflect a district that has walked away from its obligation to prepare young people for the workforce, higher education, and civic life.

Chronic absenteeism and low achievement correlate closely with higher rates of youth crime. Chicago's public-safety challenges cannot be separated from the fact that tens of thousands of teenagers are disconnected from school. No city with these levels of absenteeism and academic collapse can expect improvements in long-term safety.

This pattern of misused funds and misplaced priorities is not limited to Chicago. New York lawmakers continue to steer resources away from academics and toward politically acceptable initiatives. 

In New York's 2025 "People's Budget," Democrats—including Mayor-elect Zohran Mamdani, who was serving in the Assembly at the time—proposed an $8 million initiative to "increase teacher diversity" through new recruitment and training programs. Yet New York City's teaching workforce is already about 42 percent black, nearly double the city's black population share of roughly 22 percent.

The same budget allocates $250,000 for "racial and cultural inclusivity" initiatives, $3 million for an Adirondack exhibit on African American history, and over $350,000 for statewide conventions for "underrepresented" educators. 

Meanwhile, NYC public schools serve 154,000 homeless students, and nearly half of the students statewide cannot meet basic reading benchmarks. New York spends more than $39,000 per pupil—the highest amount in the country—yet academic outcomes continue to fall.

If the problem were money, New York would be leading the nation. But this is a crisis of priorities.

Charter schools offer a proven alternative that disrupts the cycle of low achievement and disengagement. Unlike traditional public schools, charter schools provide students with 30 percent to 50 percent more instructional time. This extra time correlates directly with stronger academic performance and higher rates of student engagement.

A study found that entering a North Carolina charter school in ninth grade was associated with a roughly 30 percent reduction in a student's likelihood of committing a crime compared with students in traditional public schools. Research from Milwaukee's voucher program found that students in choice programs were significantly less likely to commit crimes as young adults.

School choice gives students in failing districts an exit ramp. Programs in Florida, Arizona, and North Carolina show that scholarship and charter systems can coexist with public schools and often improve them through competition.

Chicago's waste, New York's misplaced priorities, and the falling academic performance nationwide all point to the same conclusion: Families—not bureaucracies—should decide where and how children are educated.

summary: Friedrich Hayek's most popular work was dedicated to "the socialists of all parties." That phrase perfectly captures politics in 2025.
title: To the Socialists of All Parties
text:
Reason has a rule against starting essays with quotes from Friedrich Hayek. After all, one could start nearly every essay in this magazine with a bon mot from the Austrian-born economist and classical liberal hero. But sometimes things get bad enough that only a Hayek quote will do.

In this month's cover story, where Eric Boehm documents how the GOP has been slouching toward socialism, he kicks
things off with Hayek's warning that economic nationalism can be "the bridge from conservatism to collectivism" and that thinking in terms of "our" industries is only a short step from demanding that they be "directed in the national interest."

President Donald Trump's second-term "national champion" economic strategy has metastasized from tariffs and jawboning to direct control: a golden share in U.S. Steel and government equity stakes in Intel, MP Materials, Lithium Americas, and Trilogy Metals. No longer veiling every power grab under the guise of responding to an emergency, he is presenting these as necessary for national security and other ongoing
national interests. The result, Boehm argues, will be more state control of the commanding heights, and that will invite politicized decision making, bad bets, and the well-documented underperformance that tends to follow when the state takes seats in corporate boardrooms.

Is this socialism? The word was chosen advisedly. What Trump is doing is more akin to state capitalism, for now. You might even consider whether the term fascism applies, if you want to pick a fight rather than change minds.

But once upon a time, Republicans were at least moderately chastened by accusations that their policies resembled socialism in any way. For at least a couple of decades, a staple among the conservative chattering classes was to lament that the kids these days keep telling pollsters they prefer socialism to capitalism. They're still doing it: In an October Axios–Generation Lab poll of college students, 67 percent hold a positive or neutral association with the word socialism, compared with 40 percent with the word capitalism.

This political moment is captured perfectly in Hayek's dedication of The Road to Serfdom: "To the socialists of all parties." As Reason goes to press with an issue accusing the GOP of socialist tendencies, a self-described socialist has just been elected mayor of New York City. Zohran Mamdani ran on a platform of rent freezes, higher minimum wages, free buses, new taxes on the wealthy, and city-run grocery stores. The BBC, covering Mamdani's successful campaign, noted that democratic socialism "has no clear definition"—fair enough—but then preposterously went on to say that it "essentially means giving a voice to workers, not corporations."

Both in New York and in Washington, D.C., officials are still just taking baby steps toward state control of the economy. But baby steps in the wrong direction add up, especially when they build new precedents for government ownership as a routine policy tool rather than a last-ditch response to crisis.

When a government marries price
controls, nationalizations, and an ever-expanding definition of "strategic" sectors, the end state is neither abundance nor resilience. Venezuela's long slide—from petro-prosperity to hyperinflation, capital
flight, shortages, and political repression—wasn't caused by just one statute or one charismatic leader, but by a theory that essential industries must be steered from the center of political power. That theory eventually consumes everything it touches, including the price mechanism, the independence of firms, and the credibility of money.

When Hayek referred to socialism, he meant state control of the economy, not the welfare state in its many guises. (Though it is worth noting that both major parties have campaigned upon pledges not to cut, reform, or otherwise bring reasonable fiscal alignment to the largest entitlement programs.) On that narrower definition, the United States in 2025 is far from true socialism.

It is, however, troublingly closer than it once was. The habit of using state power to override market choices is growing on both left and right. Republicans increasingly justify industrial policy as a national security imperative; Democrats often insist on "public options" across sectors. In both cases, the mechanism is the same: Redefine "our" interests so broadly that almost any private decision becomes a public question.

This is where the GOP's new enthusiasm for equity stakes should alarm anyone who ever identified as a fan of the free market. If Washington owns a golden share, a firm's governance documents start to read like an executive branch wish list. If Washington owns 10 percent of a chipmaker, the political incentives point toward doubling down when the bet goes bad, not exiting and taking the loss. The more the state identifies with "national champions," the more capital and attention flow toward the politically connected rather than the productive. If we aren't yet on the road to serfdom, perhaps we're pulling up to the highway on-ramp.

Meanwhile in New York, the new mayor's platform highlights a different risk: the soft normalization of municipal ownership and price-setting as first-resort tools for meeting affordability goals. Even Mamdani's admirers concede that many of his ideas will run headlong into state law, institutional veto points, and budget arithmetic. That is an argument not just about feasibility but about humility. Should a city government that struggles to maintain buses on schedule try to operate grocery logistics at scale? Should it even be operating buses? As Mamdani went from long-shot candidate to frontrunner, the more ideologically edgy elements of his platform started to rapidly fall away. But counting on him to keep scaling back bad ideas is too dangerous a gamble for America's
biggest city.

Whether the pretext is "national security" or "affordability," the method is the same: replacing voluntary exchange with political allocation. Since we're already indulging ourselves, let's let Hayek have the last word: "The effect of the people's agreeing that there must be central planning, without agreeing on the ends, will be rather as if a group of people were to commit themselves to take a journey together without agreeing where they want to go; with the result that they may all have to make a journey which most of them do not want at all."

summary: 'Radical anti-American socialists'
title: Scott Jennings Says He’d Be Shocked If Democrats Don’t Nominate Socialist In 2028
text:
Republican strategist Scott Jennings asserted he would be stunned if the Democratic Party did not nominate a socialist for president in 2028 during a Manhattan Institute interview posted on Tuesday.

Jennings’ comments in the interview posted to the Manhattan Institute’s YouTube channel followed Democratic Socialist New York City Mayor-elect Zohran Mamdani’s Nov. 4 victory against former Democratic New York Gov. Andrew Cuomo. The Republican strategist predicted that the passion of the socialist wing of the Democratic Party would be unbeatable. (RELATED: Mamdani-Loving Queer Socialist Primaries Hakeem Jeffries)

“[T]hat’s where their energy is. It’s obvious. It’ll be shocking to me if they don’t nominate a socialist for president in 2028,” Jennings said. “They fought it off in ’16. They fought it off in ’20. They’re not going to fight it off in 2028.”

Manhattan Institute President Reihan Salam told Jennings he believed Democratic Kentucky Gov. Andy Beshear would win the nomination and be “flanked by socialist advisers.”

“I don’t know about that. I think someone has to be able to channel the emotional energy … You have to be able to absorb and reflect the emotional energy of the electorate,” Jennings replied. “That’s what [President Donald] Trump got about the Republicans in ’16 that none of the other 17 got. It’s what Trump got about the country last year. It’s what Mamdani, I guess, got about, you know, enough people here in New York. You have to be able to absorb and reflect the emotional energy of enough people to win.”

“And it requires a bit of showmanship. It doesn’t require advisers. It requires a bit of personal talent and showmanship. That’s part of the game now. And so my impression is it’ll be somebody like that,” he added. “It won’t be a milquetoast person going, ‘Well, but I’ve got a whole politburo here that’ll help me.’ It’ll be somebody who can personally understand the energy and reflect it back.”

Jennings said it would be difficult for Beshear to compete with a socialist candidate.

“He’ll have a hard time, I think, competing with people who are more authentically radical anti-American socialists. But that’s what the Democrats want,” he said. “They want somebody who thinks America’s rotten at the core. They want somebody who thinks capitalism has failed. And they want somebody who’d like to rip all of it out and install some other very un-American ideology. Beshear, I think, would have a hard time keeping up with the emotional energy of that.”

Independent Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders ran for president as a Democrat in 2016 and 2020. He asserted on “Flagrant” in May that both of his campaigns faced “hatred” from the “Democratic establishment.”

“[T]he establishment did not want to open the door. They hated the idea for all these people whose hands were a little bit dirty, who didn’t have PhDs or weren’t wealthy — imagine walking in: ‘It’s my party, man. You ain’t getting in. We will fight you in the most ruthless ways that we can.’ And that’s the struggle,” Sanders said. “Are they gonna open the door, or are they prepared to lose elections, literally, and … go down with the Titanic?”

title: Retail Workers Currently Earning 51.6% Less Than Needed To Afford Rent: Report
text:
Authored by Naveen Athrappully via The Epoch Times (emphasis ours),

An American retail worker earns 51.6 percent less than the amount required to afford a typical rental apartment, real estate brokerage Redfin said in a statement released on Nov. 26.

“The typical retail worker in America earns $34,436 per year,” the company said.

“A renter would need to earn $71,172 to afford the typical apartment, which costs $1,779 per month.”

This signifies a shortfall of $36,736 needed to afford an apartment, even though overall affordability has improved slightly in recent years.

In Cleveland, a typical retail worker earns 32.9 percent less than needed to afford a residence, the smallest shortfall among 40 metropolitan areas analyzed by the brokerage. This was followed by St. Louis, San Antonio, Kansas City, and Milwaukee. These places have some of the lowest rents in the country.

In contrast, the shortfall was highest in New York, where a retail worker earned 71 percent less. This was followed by Boston, San Jose, Miami, and San Diego. These locations rank among the most expensive rental locations.

Besides the rent struggle, the U.S. retail sector is also seeing large layoffs.

Retailers have announced 88,664 job cuts through October this year, a 145 percent jump compared to the same period last year, according to a Nov. 6 report by outplacement company Challenger, Gray & Christmas.

Incomes and Rent Growth

“As the cost of living has increased, so have the sacrifices renters must make to afford a place to live,” Redfin Chief Economist Daryl Fairweather said.

However, “the good news is rents are no longer rising as fast as they were during the pandemic, so rental affordability has actually improved slightly in recent years,” Fairweather added.

The average rent in a primary city residence grew by almost 3.4 percent between September 2024 and 2025, according to data from the Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis.

A Nov. 19 report from real estate marketplace Zillow noted that U.S. incomes grew faster than asking rents this year amid a general slowdown in rent growth.

“Affordability is improving most significantly in markets where rents have fallen from year-ago levels, including Austin (where the typical asking rent is down 3.1 percent annually), Denver (-2.1 percent), San Antonio (-0.8 percent), and Phoenix (-0.7 percent),” the report said.

“Though incomes have understandably outpaced rents in markets where rent growth has turned negative, affordability improvements have even reached metros where rent growth remains strong.”

A monthly rental budget of $2,000 will net different types of properties based on the region, according to a Nov. 10 report from online rental marketplace Apartments.

“Renters in smaller cities like Memphis, Buffalo, and Indianapolis can afford three-bedroom apartments within a $2,000 budget, while in big cities like Boston, Los Angeles, and Seattle, that same budget often only covers a studio,” it said.

Meanwhile, there have been proposals to freeze the amount that can be charged on rental properties.

Zohran Mamdani, a self-described democratic socialist who won the New York City mayoral race this month, proposed a rent freeze during his campaign. Washington state, Oregon, and California have already implemented statewide rent control.

Supporters of rent-freeze policies argue that such measures are required to ease the burden on American families. However, critics warn that pursuing these policies could deter investment in the rental market, further exacerbating the issue in the long run.

A survey of The Epoch Times readers conducted on Oct. 29 found that most opposed rent-freeze measures and advocated pursuing market solutions.

Nearly 40 percent suggested that builders cut costs to reduce the housing shortage, which could then bring down rents.

title: Rabbis and other Jewish NYers join Mamdani’s 400-member mayoral transition committees
text:
Five local rabbis are among the more than 400 New Yorkers tapped for New York City Mayor-elect Zohran Mamdani’s transition committees, the teams tasked with preparing his administration ahead of his Jan. 1 swearing-in.

They include Abby Stein, who appeared in “Jews for Zohran” campaigns and shares the mayor-elect’s anti-Zionist outlook, on the health committee; Ellen Lippman, who recently retired f ...

summary: Editor Chris Quinn hosts our daily half-hour news podcast, with editorial board member Lisa Garvin, impact editor Leila Atassi and content director Laura Johnston.
title: After all that fussing and whining, Strongsville does not actually need a new highway interchange? Today in Ohio
text:
CLEVELAND, Ohio - Strongsville wants a new I-71 interchange on the Brunswick border, so badly that the requirement almost became Ohio law.

But a new traffic study shows that congestion is not actually that bad. We’re talking about the long-simmering controversy on Today in Ohio.

Editor Chris Quinn hosts our daily half-hour news podcast, with editorial board member Lisa Garvin, impact editor Leila Atassi and content director Laura Johnston.

You’ve been sending Chris lots of thoughts and suggestions on our from-the-newsroom text account, in which he shares what we’re thinking about at cleveland.com. You can sign up here: https://joinsubtext.com/chrisquinn.

Here’s what we’re asking about today:

With all the fussing and fighting and kind of illegal shenanigans in the Statehouse over it, does it turn out that traffic is actually not bad enough to merit a new 

We’ve had several conversations of late about how regulators finally held FirstEnergy accountable, so why are rates for FirstEnergy customers going up while decreasing for electricity customers elsewhere in Ohio?

Most of the readers who wrote to see say they don’t care about the end of the penny. They’d like to see the nickel go away, too. But reporter Anna Staver found some business people for whom the end of the penny could be a big deal. Why?

Cleveland has its own verson of Zohran Mamdani. Who is it?

With shootings scaring people at two county fairs over the summer and hooliganism showing up at plenty of other gatherings, Cleveland had some strict rules for its Winterland kickoff in Public Square. What did the city do, and how did it work out?

We were stunned at how shabbily Cuyahoga County Executive Chris Ronayne was treating MetroHealth throughout the budget process, first taking steps that ended up shutting down the psychiatric emergency room and then slashing the county subsidy. Did county council members have a greater sense of their responsibility to this vital institution?

This seems like a surprise, given the conservation efforts of recent years, but how much has plastic pollution in Lake Erie gone up in the past decade?

Is it really all that surprising that JD Vance could not name the eight presidents who came from Ohio? Could any of us? Why is it that they are so obscure?

This is one of those stories that I guess has been flying under the radar for years. Where has a big Muslic community emerged in Northeast Ohio, and what are the plans to fortify the community there?

We have an Apple podcasts channel exclusively for this podcast. Subscribe here.

Do you get your podcasts on Spotify? Find us here.

RadioPublic is another popular podcast vehicle, and we are here.

On PodParadise, find us here.

And on PlayerFM, we are here.

Chris Quinn (00:01.003)

December 1st, three weeks for the run up to the Christmas week. We got some news to talk about though, before we get there. It’s Today in Ohio, the news podcast discussion from cleveland.com and The Plain Dealer. I’m Chris Quinn here with Laura Johnston, Lisa Garvin, and back from two weeks off, Leila Tasi. Remember Leila? I should reintroduce you to Leila. Leila, you’re up first.

With all the fussing and fighting and all kinds of kind of illegal shenanigans in the state house over it, does it turn out that traffic is actually not bad enough to merit a new highway interchange in Strongsville?

Leila (00:41.336)

Turns out maybe not, Chris. The early numbers from this big two-year NAWACA study of the I-71 corridor show that traffic in Strongsville and Brunswick is nowhere near the disaster that some lawmakers made it out to be. The engineers actually said they were surprised. Traffic is, quote, not terrible. Even after they checked the cameras, they sent up drones, they literally flew a helicopter over the mess just to be sure.

And yeah, there are pinch points, mostly around South Park Mall and a few busy intersections and garbage truck day on Howe Road is apparently its own special kind of chaos. But overall, nothing is failing today. And even looking ahead to 2050, only a few intersections slip into that, know, uh-oh territory. And that’s important because the whole reason we’re doing the study is the fight over whether to build this brand new interchange at Boston Road. Strongsville has long wanted it.

Brunswick has long said hard pass. Lawmakers have tried sneaking the interchange into the state budget more than once, only to have it yanked back out after a public backlash. Now with actual data on the table, Brunswick officials are basically saying, see, we told you so. Strongsville’s mayor is still pushing for solutions, especially for emergency vehicles. But even he admits people might accept an alternative if the study offers one. So I think the takeaway is that after all this drama,

The early evidence says traffic just isn’t bad enough to justify a brand new interchange, at least not yet.

Chris Quinn (02:12.077)

Well, this story floored me because they have made it sound like this is Armageddon for traffic. And when you talk about pinch points, have you ever been on 271 heading south during the afternoon rush hour? I mean, you have pinch points everywhere in Northeast Ohio during rush hour and bad traffic periods. You learn if you can to avoid it. And if you can’t, you get stuck in it. This doesn’t sound like it’s anything worse.

than many of the areas that we encounter on any day. just, what brought this to the fever pitch that they so desperately wanted this intersection because the traffic clearly doesn’t justify it.

Lisa Garvin (02:50.662)

Leila (02:53.934)

Yeah, I don’t know. mean, I think the study still has 13 months to go, but yeah, the crisis that they described doesn’t show up in the numbers. I think it’s fascinating that the data is forcing a reality check on this debate that’s been driven by politics. Let’s be honest, that’s what’s really behind this. If the numbers continue to show that congestion isn’t the monster it’s been made out to be, then they really need to kind of shift the conversation from where do we build a new interchange to how do we make the system we already have work?

Lisa Garvin (03:03.622)

that’s the reality that number two, the patient’s needs have been driven by common sense. But to be honest, that’s really kind of, the numbers continue to show that suggestion isn’t a loss, it’s a loss. But they really need to kind of shift the conversation around. Where do we build community? How do we make the system here better place? That might be what we need to be talking about as well.

Leila (03:23.79)

mean, that might be what we need to be talking about in Strongsville. And that will open the door to cheaper, faster fixes. You’ll get signal timing, turn lane tweaks, stuff like that. Coordinating with delivery trucks. There are ways to make it easier on residents and people who are regularly driving that.

Chris Quinn (03:34.765)

Chris Quinn (03:41.325)

Yeah, but hold on. I mean, we’re supposed to base our traffic spending on priorities. And I think based on the way this sounds, my bet is if you looked at all of the traffic areas that are problematic in Northeast Ohio, this wouldn’t rank that high. I Lisa, you drive around in the daytime, don’t you hit pinch points?

Lisa Garvin (04:00.13)

Mm-hmm. Yeah, all over the place. I mean, east side, west side, south side, they’re just kind of all over the place.

Chris Quinn (04:03.22)

Chris Quinn (04:08.459)

I mean, I don’t think that the loudest screaming should result in the fastest spending. I think we should look at the region as a whole, which is the whole point of NOACA. Where is traffic the worst? And that’s where you spend the money. And if this study shows that these people are just whining, it’s not that bad, then I don’t think we should be spending any money there. Maybe change their garbage day or something.

Leila (04:29.728)

I think, well, I think that we should applaud the fact that the system so far has worked in this case, because look at how hard they tried to move this project to the front of the queue and get it done and just ram it through when finally we’re seeing some data that doesn’t support the necessity for it. So hooray, we haven’t wasted public money on something that was unnecessary.

Chris Quinn (04:53.633)

Except we came very close. I Patton put in the law, which was pretty much not even legal because you have to work with the federal government on stuff like this. there were a bunch of shenanigans involved in this that brought this to a head. Look, did anybody expect that this study would come back and say what it shows so far? Not a chance. No, because of all the squawking. So you’re right. It’s good that we have some real data. Great story. just it floored me.

Leila (04:58.884)

Leila (05:16.611)

Chris Quinn (05:26.509)

You’re listening to Today in Ohio. We’ve had several conversations of late about how regulators finally held first energy accountable and wouldn’t give them the money that they kept trying to pull out of our pockets. So Laura, I was surprised by this story. Why are rates for first energy customers going up while they’re decreasing for electricity customers elsewhere in Ohio?

Laura (05:48.462)

Well, and it’s not even all First Energy customers. So First Energy has three Ohio subsidiaries. Only one, thank you, Northeast Ohio, is going to see the base electric rates go up by about $5 per month for the average residential user. Ohio Edison and Toledo Edison will actually have their base rates go down by a few dollars per month. So it’s just the illuminating customers that are going to see an increase. And these base rates have been in place for as long as, I believe,

four years, they’re just one component that affect the power bills. Obviously, we’ve got to deal with spiking electricity prices and all of the usage. But this is from the PUCO ruling. It’s a compromise. Actually, the Ohio Consumers Council wanted First Energy to slash its annual rates by more than $132 million. First Energy, meanwhile, wanted to collect $190 million more per year. It wanted a profit margin of 10.8%, which I read that I just wanted to like.

shoot a dart at somebody. And the PUCO said, no, 9.63 % is what you’re going to get. And the reason that the illuminating company customers, us, are seeing this base rate increase is because the cost of maintaining the electricity grid in Northeast Ohio is more expensive than elsewhere and not what they anticipated, maybe because they didn’t use their grid modernization fee to actually modernize the grid, which is what we were talking about recently on the podcast.

Chris Quinn (07:14.477)

Yeah, I did hear from some of the listeners and others who read the podcast story about that. And while they don’t trust First Energy to actually spend the money to fix up the grid, they do wish that some independent agency that the state could monitor could come in and spend that money on the grid. They really don’t want the money back. They want reliable power systems. And if this is the reason we have higher rates, all the more reason to fix the grid.

Laura (07:34.688)

Laura (07:42.092)

Chris Quinn (07:42.731)

I wish First Energy would be forced to divest itself so that we could get some kind of responsible owner of that system in so that we would stop talking about these nightmares.

Laura (07:53.742)

Yeah, you know what I was floored by in this story was that the PUCL also blocked First Energy from continuing to earn profits on their tree trimming and line clearing work. So I guess between 2007 and 2021, they had nearly $270 million of that work. And then they charged customers an extra fee on top of that. They’re not doing the work themselves. They’re paying for someone to do it. But they took an upcharge for that. And so

This is vegetation management with a profit and the PUC, was saying, you actually cannot do that. And that to me is just galling that they were paying somebody to do the work they should have been doing and then charging us extra on top of what they were paying.

Chris Quinn (08:33.739)

Yeah, we’ll pay what it costs, but you shouldn’t make extra money on it because you’ve allowed your system to become so overgrown. They had not been good about trimming trees. That’s one of the reasons we had the blackout back in the day. And now to hear they’re trying to make a profit on it boggles the mind. They just are thieves. Any way they can nickel and dime us.

Laura (08:36.556)

Laura (08:48.759)

Chris Quinn (08:58.049)

They do instead of running a responsible utility. And yet they’ll tell you today, we’re not the same utility that bribe the state house into oblivion. We’re a better company today. When are we going to see a sign of that?

Laura (09:03.735)

Laura (09:09.623)

I don’t know.

Chris Quinn (09:11.019)

You’re listening to Today in Ohio. Most of the readers who wrote to me say they don’t care about the end of the penny and they’d actually like to see the nickel go away too. But Lisa reporter Anna Staver found some business people who think the end of the penny could be a big deal for them. Why?

Lisa Garvin (09:14.342)

Lisa Garvin (09:28.3)

It’s already starting to be a big deal. You know, the last penny rolled out of the mint on November 12th and it was kind of sudden. They usually phase out currency over years, but there are no federal or state rules on rounding purchases to the nearest nickel. Many businesses are already running short. I was in a Goodwill yesterday. They were putting up signs saying we don’t have pennies. And the question is, do you round up or down?

So the Federal Reserve Bank of Richmond in July in their economic brief suggested a common rounding rule. So totals that end in three, four, eight or nine cents are rounded up. Totals ending in one, two, six or seven get rounded down. But a Federal Reserve study found that rounding usually isn’t in the customer’s favor and it costs consumers $6 million a year. So in the Federal Reserve study 2024 purchases, they found that

In America, 14 % of people paid cash last year. Big variances by age. If you’re 55 or over, it was 19 % paying cash. If you’re 18 to 24, only 10 % were paying cash. So this is already a mess. We talked to the president of the Ohio Restaurant and Hospitality Alliance, John Barker. He says it’s a real mess. He says most people are uncomfortable with rounding up without a law.

but he rounding down could be a significant business loss. And then what happens to the extra pennies? There’s no guidance on taxing it, tracking it, or you know, it’s profit. Is it getting pocketed? Where does it go?

Chris Quinn (11:01.293)

I’m surprised that this is this much of a hardship because the most they can round up your purchase is going to be four cents, right? Because otherwise you’re at the nickel level and given how much inflation is devalued currency, are people really going to be hurt by a four cent roundup?

Lisa Garvin (11:23.91)

I say yes, pennies add up and you know, think that’s extra profit that they don’t have to track a report at this point. You know, so if you take three or four pennies from 100 customers a day, that’s a lot of money.

Chris Quinn (11:38.027)

Well, think about if they follow through with the nickel, which they can make a financial argument for that will really turn things upside down. You’re listening to Today in Ohio. All right, Laila Cleveland has its own version of Zoran Mamdani. Who is it?

Leila (11:55.139)

The answer is Tanmay Shah in Ward 12. He just pulled off exactly the kind of upset that Mamdani became famous for in New York City. Two years ago, Shah stood at the Cleveland City Council podium and basically told Blaine Griffin and the city’s power brokers, go ahead and collect your checks from billionaires. We’re coming for you and you can’t stop us. finally, after every last provisional and mail ballot was tallied, he proved it.

He beat incumbent Danny Kelly by nine votes. Nine votes. That’s about as slim as it gets. Shaw is a 29-year-old democratic socialist. He’s a former legal aid attorney who quit his job to drive trucks part-time so he could spend the rest of his time organizing. He built his entire campaign around the idea that City Hall isn’t listening. They’re not listening on housing, not on basic services. And he ran the most left-leaning tenant-focused platform in the entire field.

and he mailed out guides on how renters can fight late fees and force repairs. He hammered affordability and he rode that grassroots energy all the way to victory. And what makes this even more mumdani-esque, I guess you could say, is who he beat. He beat a union-backed incumbent with the full weight of Mayor Bibb and Blaine Griffin behind him. He had the establishment pretty locked up and still this democratic socialist from War 12 cracked through.

And he wasn’t the only progressive that got onto council. Nikki Hudson was backed by the same progressive groups. She also won in Ward 11. So it’s not just one upset. It’s the beginning of this real left flank forming inside Cleveland politics.

Chris Quinn (13:33.697)

What’s interesting about this is about six weeks before the election, I had heard that he was getting some real traction and I was talking to a significant person in City Hall and I mentioned it and I was just kind of pushed aside. No, no. Kelly’s got this going away. There’s no contest here. It’s like, OK, we’ll see. And they couldn’t have been more wrong. I love the way that Sean McDonald framed this victory in writing the story. It shows the value.

of having somebody that knows what they’re talking about doing it instead of some transcriptionist because he framed it the way you just did that this is a big moment. He had said, you are not responding to the needs of the people. I’m coming into city hall to change things. He is not going to be one of Boehn-Griffin’s favorites because he is going to be in his face, I think saying the status quo has got to go.

all those traditional city hall types, they always stand on tradition and all their stupid little habits and things. This guy sounds like he’s a change agent and he’s going to be calling them out.

Leila (14:40.72)

I think on a very big level we’re going to see that too because we always have said for years and years that council members are so focused on their tiny corner of Cleveland that that’s where the votes come from. So that’s what they care about most getting for their neighborhoods and their ward. It’s so fiefdom oriented. But what struck me most when Shaw sat with our editorial board was that

His politics are really grounded in this deep understanding of the structural problems that are hollowing out his city, especially when it comes to housing. He wasn’t railing against the establishment for the sake of it. He was really talking about eviction rates, displacement, and how everyday families are being priced out of housing. And that’s the interesting parallel with, know, Mumdani, I think. So strip away the labels of democratic socialist and insurgent or whatever.

You’re really left with someone who’s laser focused on how regular people are supposed to live with dignity in a city where rent is rising and services are shaky and the systems that are meant to protect them don’t always do their job. And I was really moved by that. He has a very big picture view of Cleveland for someone who’s elected to represent a ward. We need people on council who have that perspective.

Chris Quinn (15:58.445)

Yeah, I wonder what he thinks about the unit rule where he’s required to cast his vote unanimously for the council president or get kicked out of all the caucuses. Doesn’t sound like he voted, but it doesn’t sound like he’s going to be greatly in favor of that kind of nonsense. You’re listening to Today in Ohio with shootings scaring people at two county fairs over the summer and hooliganism showing up at plenty of other gatherings. Cleveland had some strict rules for its winterland kickoff, Laura, down in Public Square.

Leila (16:02.704)

Chris Quinn (16:27.489)

What did the city do? How did it work out?

Laura (16:30.251)

This worked. It’s great because of the 40 year tradition is a Cleveland special time and everybody was safe. They had new site tighter security that forced kids under 18 to be accompanied by an adult. And the way that they did this is they had only five entry points for those attending. And if you’ve been to public square, there’s a whole lot of entry points. There’s roads all around it. So they blocked off those roads starting, I believe at 7 a.m. that morning and set up these checkpoints where you had to come through. If you were under 18, you needed a 21.

your old guardian with you basically. And instead of making this a one-time deal where they turn on the lights of the big tree, they had a lot of different illuminate clea light shows beginning at 5 30 p.m. and repeating every 30 minutes through 11 30. So if you caught it at eight or you caught it at, you know, 10, it was the same show. So there was no huge crowd and they were trying to spread it out all through the day and through the season. So there’s not just so many people packed into one space because

We’ve talked about it, you and me, like around this podcast, would you take your family to something where you wonder if something bad could happen? Two years ago, a 15 year old shot two other teams. They were 13 and 15 and there were some skirmishes last year. That’s not what you want to be dealing with when you want holiday joy. So I’m so glad that they kept this safe.

Chris Quinn (17:51.169)

I’m impressed they did it. When they first announced it, I thought this would be a challenge, but they took the right tack. The only way you can keep a crowd safe is to have checkpoints as people come in. We’ve seen it not just locally, but across the nation. When people get together, all you need is a couple of teenagers with the hormones raging that have guns, and people get killed and people get hurt. And it does cast a pall on these public gatherings. I wonder if

Laura (18:06.146)

Chris Quinn (18:20.331)

The message we’ll get out now for future gatherings that it’s okay. If they have another concert downtown, the orchestra plays a concert, do they do the same thing? And is there a way to do it at Edgewater Fireworks, for instance? Because otherwise people will be afraid of getting together in crowds. We’ve heard from our readers about it. We’ve talked about it here. Unless you can do something concrete to provide that safety, I people stay away.

Laura (18:48.525)

I agree. It’s not something you want to put yourself or your kids in harm’s way. And this is a wonderful event. Like I said, 40 years of it. And they had Santa and the Grinch and s’more pits and food trucks and pop-up bars. It brings people to all the restaurants downtown if there’s not a Browns game or a Cavs game, right? It is an economic development driver. know that there’s Christmas merchandise at the Cleveland shops.

All of this is good and people feel good about their hometown and it’s easy to get to if you take your public transportation. So I’m glad it was a success. The photos that John Coons took were gorgeous. We had them in our extra edition and online. But it’ll be there all season. I’m going to go this coming weekend to the skating rink so you can go enjoy it.

Chris Quinn (19:34.869)

When we talked about this stuff over the summer, I asked if you would take your kids to these kinds of gatherings and you said hard pass. Would this change your mind? I knew it. That’s why I asked the question. You’re listening to Today in Ohio. We were stunned at how shabbily Cuyahoga County executive Chris Renane was treating MetroHealth throughout the budget process. First taking steps that ended up shutting down.

Leila (19:42.286)

I don’t think so.

Laura (19:43.382)

Leila (19:46.736)

You know me too well.

Chris Quinn (20:03.083)

the psychiatric emergency room and then slashing the county subsidy. Layla, did the county council members have a greater sense of their responsibility to this vital institution?

Leila (20:13.22)

They did. It turns out that county council absolutely felt more responsibility than Chris Rene did to restoring MetroHealth because while Ronane spent the entire budget season insisting that MetroHealth could absorb a multi-million dollar cut and made budget moves that helped shutter that psychiatric unit in the end, county council said, no, no, put that money back. And not just the three million that Ronane cut for next year, they restored the full

$35 million annual subsidy, even though MetroHealth CEO had tried to play it cool and say that they could make do. So what changed here, county council members basically said they didn’t buy it. Dale Miller, the council president called MetroHealth situation too uncertain and too risky to gamble on. Charity care is exploding. I mean, more than a million dollars a day and looming Medicaid changes could yank thousands of low income patients off the rolls. And if that happens, MetroHealth gets stuck holding the bag.

Because the county backs MetroHealth’s debt with a $64 million letter of credit, a hospital financial crisis becomes the county’s crisis. So council members, including Michael Gallagher, Sonny Simon, they were really blunt about this. They didn’t believe MetroHealth was fine and they weren’t willing to starve the safety net hospital just to balance the books on paper. So they reached into reserves, they restored that full subsidy, even though it does blow a hole in the Health and Human Services levy fund. And the trade off is a little bit harsh because

Council prioritized MetroHealth so heavily, almost nobody else got their money back, not the Adams Board, not the homeless shelter, not Juvenile Court, not Youth Services. Those cuts are all going to stand. So MetroHealth, it seems, was the big winner this budget season.

Chris Quinn (21:54.923)

I would love to see each of the county officials show their priority list for county services, because I would think MetroHealth should be way up at the top. Children and family services way up at the top. Sheriff’s downtown patrol unit way down at the bottom. But I’d love to see it, because that is how they should make these decisions. And it sounds like with MetroHealth, they made the right one. We can’t let MetroHealth suffer. It does too many vital services for

way too many people and I’m glad that they had the responsibility to fix this. I wish they could have kept the psychiatric emergency room open.

Leila (22:33.934)

Yeah. mean, what council did here was really step back and look at the long game, because like you said, Chris, Metro Health is the backbone of the county’s entire safety net system. If that hospital falters, every vulnerable population in the region pays that price. So by restoring the subsidy, council’s saying, we’re not going to wait for a crisis to prove that these cuts were a mistake. It’s really rare in government, I think, to see proactive decision making instead of clean up after the fact.

But that’s really what this is. It’s this recognition that protecting MetroHealth now is far cheaper than trying to rebuild it after collapse.

Chris Quinn (23:09.889)

The Council’s had a very good focus on this whole budget process. Caitlin Durbin’s done a wonderful job reporting it, but they have been holding Chris Renane accountable in all sorts of ways, including what we’ve discussed previously about the Sheriff’s Office. Seems like they took their responsibility very seriously this budget season and examined it closely. They were not buying the executives’ nonsense. They were digging in themselves.

Leila (23:14.98)

Leila (23:35.781)

Yeah. You want to, you mentioned Caitlin Durbin. I just want to give her props here for really focusing the lens on these important issues from day one. She’s the one who dug into the details of his cut, Ronin’s cuts, connected them to the closure of the psych ER, kept pressing officials on the ripple effects. So her reporting really made it impossible for anyone to pretend that Metro Health situation was just another routine budget tweak. And I just really appreciate.

everything that she’s done to kind of force transparency throughout this budget season.

Chris Quinn (24:07.723)

Yeah. Yeah, it’s been a public service. You’re listening to Today in Ohio. Lisa, this one seems like a surprise to me given the conservation efforts of recent years, but how much has plastic pollution in Lake Erie gone up in the past decade?

Lisa Garvin (24:24.778)

It’s actually pretty eye popping this is research by sherry mason who’s at the university in iri pennsylvania she’s a freshwater researcher and she first looked at plastic back in twenty fourteen and then checked again last year going to the same five sites every single one of them was up as far as plastic particles found in the water and she was actually expecting mixed results she thought it’d be lower in some areas and higher and others.

So three central basin sites that she looked at from Cleveland to Canada, there were 98,000 plastic particles per kilometer closest to Cleveland. That doubled in 10 years. In the middle of the lake in the central basin, 92,000 parts per kilometer. And that was up from 38,000, but most of it’s close to Canada. And a lot of this has to do with the way the lake flows anyway. But 188,000,

thousand particles per kilometer closest to Canada. That was up from only 16,000 10 years before. And it’s much more dramatic in the Eastern end near Buffalo because you know, that’s where the water gets pushed towards the Eastern end of the lake. And I think the highest that we saw was 700,000 particles per kilometer off the Pennsylvania coast up from only 19,000. And this is stuff that she’s just scraping off the surface.

She says they’re missing what’s down below, know, plastic will get slime and algae and it’ll sink to the bottom. They didn’t even get to that stuff.

Chris Quinn (25:53.389)

I’m really trying to understand the why of this because we have had some much more serious plastic conservation methods in the past 10 years than we had before her 2014 study. And I’m wondering, is this possibly coming from other states or is it coming from Canada? Lake Huron is the biggest source of water in Lake Erie, unless my sources are wrong on this. It’s way more than runoff, way more than the little rivers that feed into it. So is it coming that way or?

Another thought I had, there’s a thought that house paint is a significant contributor of particle plastics now because it’s latex and it washes off in the rain. Is it possible that the more intense storms we have today are washing more of that paint out into the sewers and into the lake? Because this just doesn’t make sense. I hope there’s some analysis done.

on what the plastic is specifically so that you can start identifying what the source is because what else where’s it coming from how could it go up that much in 10 years when people have moved away from plastic bags and things like that.

Lisa Garvin (27:05.274)

Well, she mentioned COVID. She also talked about more intense storms. It drags larger plastic peaches off the beach and into the water where they get circulated around for years sometimes and get broken down. Most of what she found was about the size of a grain of rice or smaller. But also too, she talked about COVID when we were, know, people had all kinds of disposable things, know, medical waste, masks, things that people were just throwing away. And she feel, and you have to remember that when you wash,

Your clothes, plastic particles off your synthetic clothes are getting into the water too.

Laura (27:40.142)

Can I jump in here? Cause I saw your note, Chris, about flaming Canada. And I was like, no, we are not going to blame Canada for this because yes. So the majority of water is coming from Lake Huron through Lake St. Clair and the Detroit river into Lake Erie. But Lake Erie has the biggest, most populated, densely populated watershed in the Great Lakes. 12 million people live within the Lake Erie watershed. That’s about a third of the total population of the entire Great Lakes watershed.

Leila (27:47.8)

Laura (28:09.997)

Lake Erie is the shallowest Great Lake, has the least amount of water. I think that’s why it gets so densely polluted because we don’t have a lot of water to offset all the pollution that’s flowing in. The biggest Canadian city on the Great Lakes that’s not on Lake Ontario like Toronto is Thunder Bay, which is about 110,000 people. There’s not a lot of people that live on the Canadian shores of the Great Lakes.

So my thought is maybe there could be a lot of pollution coming from Detroit. I mean, all of that water has to flow through there to get into Lake Erie. But I agree with Lisa that we’re just not even cognizant of all of the ways that we are putting crap into the water. All those water bottles that people drink, those are terrible.

Chris Quinn (28:49.527)

we’ve always done that. I mean, that we were doing that before 2014. What has changed so dramatically from 2014 to now? Again, I hope there’s an analysis of the plastic unless you know what kind of plastic it is and what the possible sources can be. I don’t think we can get at it. But this should be distressing to anybody who lives in the Great Lakes. This is where we get our drinking water from. This is a serious environmental hazard.

Laura (29:14.871)

Chris Quinn (29:19.646)

And it seems like we need to invest a lot more money in figuring it out.

Laura (29:23.649)

Chris Quinn (29:25.121)

You’re listening to Today in Ohio. We’re only going to get seven stories today. Hot ones. We’ll leave a couple more for the discussion on Tuesday. Thanks, Laura. Thanks, Lisa. Thanks, Leila. Thank you for being with us today in Ohio. We’ll be back on Tuesday.

title: What We Got Wrong in November
text:
On November 3, we updated an edition of The Morning Dispatch to remove a line that overstated the destructive potential of current nuclear stockpiles.

On November 3, we updated an edition of The Morning Dispatch to remove an item about BP selling its American oil and gas business holdings.

On November 3, we updated an article about AI usage in churches to reflect the correct time period that Christopher Benek prepares sermons in advance using AI.

On November 5, we updated an edition of The Morning Dispatch to correct the spelling of Zohran Mamdani’s surname.

On November 11, we updated an edition of The Morning Dispatch to correct the number of privately owned housing units built in the United States last year. 

On November 17, we updated an edition of Wanderland to correct the math used to calculate the total cost of an employee.

On November 18, we updated an edition of The Morning Dispatch to note that a recent flight was the second for Blue Origin’s New Glenn rocket.

On November 20, we updated an edition of The Morning Dispatch to correct the size of the fall in the value of Bitcoin.

On November 24, we updated an article about Larry Summers’ relationship with Jeffrey Epstein to correct the year in which Silvio Berlusconi made the “sign of the horns” toward Josep Piqué.
